author: ANDREW KESHNER
title: Judge rules El Chapo will appear in person at Brooklyn court
text:
Judge rules El Chapo will appear in person — not via video — for Brooklyn court date Judge rules El Chapo will appear in person at Brooklyn court Judge Brian Cogan had said previously that El Chapo should appear via video conferencing "to minimize disruption from physical transportation." (HANDOUT/REUTERS) NEW YORK DAILY NEWS   6:20 PM 
Joaquin (El Chapo) Guzman will be coming back to Brooklyn for a Friday court date, a federal judge ruled Wednesday. 
Judge Brian Cogan ruled the extradited Mexican drug lord should be produced for the initial status conference in his drug trafficking case. 
Cogan previously said he was inclined to have Guzman — who made two prison breaks in Mexico — appear through video conferencing. 
This was "in order to minimize disruption from physical transportation," said Cogan. 
After hearing from both sides on the matter and considering topics for the conference, Cogan said Guzman should appear. 
Guzman’s lawyers at Federal Defenders of New York pressed for Guzman's production every time the defense and prosecution met in court. 
Their client had a right to be present in his own case, especially when he was questioning the legality of his extradition, they said. Inside the safe house and escape tunnel used by Mexican drug lord 'El Chapo' 
Guzman’s absence also would give the public the impression he was too dangerous for a courtroom and make for prejudicial pretrial publicity, they added. He is locked up for 23 hours a day at Metropolitan Correctional Center in downtown Manhattan, according to the defense. 
Brooklyn prosecutors said if the judge was going to look into Guzman's financial eligibility for appointed counsel, they had no problem with his presence. 
The government calls Guzman, 62, the billionaire leader of the Sinaloa Cartel and said a "strenuous" inquiry by the court was needed to be sure taxpayers aren't needlessly footing Guzman's legal bills. 
But if Cogan was not going to get into Guzman's financials in court, they advised video conferencing. 
Prosecutors pointed to his past prison escapes, as well as the burden on the U.S. Marshals, the costs and traffic problems connected with bringing Guzman to court. Join the Conversation:
